Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story: I glanced at my phone, seeing a message from my sister: “We’re all going to the new café tonight. Hope you can make it!” I knew how much she valued these outings, how we’d promised to be more present in each other’s lives. As her brother, I wanted to show her that she mattered, that I respected our bond enough to make time for her. But as I looked at the stack of law journals on my desk, my heart sank. The latest issue had just arrived, filled with articles on emerging legal theories—exactly the kind of material I needed to stay sharp as a judge. The expectation to remain current in my field was unspoken but ever-present, and I felt the weight of it pressing on me. I stared at the clock, torn between the warmth of family and the cold necessity of professional diligence. My mind raced, wrestling with the guilt of possibly letting my sister down and the anxiety of falling behind in my duties.
